Thermal energy storage (TES) systems with phase change materials (PCMs) as a known energy storage technology have a high potential for increasing the energy efficiency of buildings. In fact, the use of PCMs with various approaches, either active or passive, in the building helps to maintain the temperature in the thermal comfort range for occupants through decreasing the temperature swings, and lower energy consumption by the load reduction/shifting. Due to the significance of this issue, many research works have been carried out on the application of PCMs in buildings. In this study, the experimental works

in the fields of PCMs in buildings are taken into account. The papers are classified based on heating, cooling, and air-conditioning. Besides these, the applications of nano-PCMs in buildings are reviewed. According to what has been carried out up to now, the gaps are identified and analyzed for preparing useful suggestions for future works. The recommendations and suggestions are presented at the end of the chapters as well as the conclusion, and the literature is summarized in some tables.

2. Applications of PCMs in buildings for cooling
Nowadays, due to the increasing advances in technology, the advent of advanced thermal gains in buildings, the problems of global warming and increasing the need to thermal comfort, have led to increasing the cooling demand in the building sector [30,31]. Thus, finding the appropriate solutions for increasing the efficiency of cooling systems in buildings through the reduction interior temperature swings and maintaining a space at cold conditions have been highly regarded [29]. Among those solutions, the applications of PCMs into passive and active systems in buildings could be notified.
2.1. Free-cooling passive methods
In the free cooling passive, the air temperature difference between day and night, during warm seasons, lead to storing the air coolness during the night by PCM-TES and automatically releasing during the day. In fact, the PCM-TES, integrated with buildings materials, through melting and solidification process causes cool down building without any energy to produce a cold source. This method is different with the mechanical ventilation and advanced natural ventilation, in which an air exchange occurs by the mechanical fan. The use of free cooling technology reduces the need for mechanical ventilation, also leads to improve the indoor air quality, and decrease the greenhouse gasses. The potential of the freecooling with PCM to decrease the building cooling load depends directly on the domain of the ambient air temperature fluctuations.

3. Applications of PCMs in buildings for heating
3.1. Heating passive methods
In passive heating applications, PCMs have been used into the building components such as floors, walls, and roofs. By absorbing the solar heat during the daytime and releasing during the night, the process of melting and solidification results in heating the indoor environment in cold seasons. There are several studies associated with the application of PCM in the passive heating systems in buildings, which that are discussed in this section.
Athienitis et al. [66] used gypsum, impregnated with PCM, for coating the interior walls in a passive solar test room. Their experimental and simulation results showed that this type of lining helped to decrease the heating load at night, and prevent overheating during the day. Zhang et al. [67] assessed the use of shape-stabilized PCMs in different parts of building such as floor, wall, and ceiling for heat energy storage in winter. They found that using the shape-stabilized PCM, without the need for encapsulating the PCM, could create a simpler heat energy storage unit. Shilei et al. [68] constructed a phase change wallboard by combining gypsum boards and PCM for applying in passive solar buildings. Then, the thermal performance of the PCM wall room was compared with the usual wall room in a city in China during the winter. The results demonstrated that using PCM wallboard in the building could improve the indoor temperature, and help to save the energy cost and electrical power.

Furthermore, adding nanoparticles with high thermal conductivity in the PCM base fluid leads to enhance the thermal conductivity and energy saving density of PCMs. Nowadays, the use of these new products (nano-enhanced PCMs) has been the center of attention for the applications in buildings.
